Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Ruthenium Catalyzed Reactions Leading to New Polymer Architectures and Improved Chemical Recyclability of Plastics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plastics are made from polymers and polymer manufacture represents one of the largest and most dynamic sectors of the chemical industry. Companies are targeting better performing polymer materials derived from more economical and environmentally friendly (bio-renewable) feedstocks. These improvements are often driven by chemical advancements in polymer synthesis research, such as the work supported by this award. It is critical to the field of polymer chemistry to improve the basic understanding of the relationships between polymer structure and the properties of the resulting plastic, which is a primary goal of this research. Undergraduate students, including low income and first generation college students, perform laboratory work for this study and receive valuable training to prepare them for graduate school and/or employment in the chemical industry.

With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Prof. Robertson of Northland College and Prof. Carney of the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire conduct collaborative research to better understand the properties of ruthenium catalysts in polymerization reactions. Specifically, this project focuses on making advancements in five key areas: (1) preparation of polymers from bio-renewable monomers, such as 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), (2) polymer alternatives to polyurethanes (found in many paints, varnishes, adhesives, and foams), (3) increasing the utility of commodity plastics, (4) depolymerization methods to produce useful chemicals from waste plastics, and (5) synthesis of new ruthenium compounds to better understand the impacts of chemical structure on the catalyst's performance. Toward this end, the research team is synthesizing and studying new ruthenium catalysts with structurally versatile N-phosphinoamidine and beta-diketimine ligand backbones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.

The primary outcome of the project was the development of synthetic methods for the synthesis of polyureas and polycycloacetals, two classes of polymeric materials that are formed from readily available building blocks (monomers) and often with high levels of biorenewable content. For the polycycloacetals, one of the monomers is diglycerol, which is readily prepared from glycerol. The latter is produced in large quantities as a co-product during biodiesel production. To date, the commercial market for glycerol has not kept pace with its production, however the potential large-scale use of diglycerol in the synthesis of polycycloacetals may provide a useful outlet for this inexpensive and readily available starting material. For the polycycloacetals, the polymers displayed a wide range of commercially useful properties - from rigid to flexible to elastomeric - with the properties being tunable based on the amounts and types of monomers used. For both classes of polymers, the synthetic procedures were designed to be reversible, meaning that the polymers could conceivably be unzipped and chemically recycled into their constituent monomers for reuse, thereby reducing the environmental impact of the polymers.

The results of the polyurea and polycycloacetal work were disseminated to the scientific community via poster presentations at a national meeting of the American Chemical Society in 2018 and the 2019 Green Chemistry and Engineering conference, respectively. The polycycloacetal work was also accepted for publication in the Journal of Applied Polymer Science.

A second outcome of the project was the design and synthesis of transition metal compounds to serve as potential hydrogenation and dehydrogenation catalysts. The intent is for these catalysts to find use in the preparation of polyesters and polyamides from renewable resources. Several of the transition metal compounds were structurally characterized by x-ray crystallography, which confirmed their identities.

Broader Impacts.

A third outcome was the training and professional development provided to our undergraduate researchers. The research team consisted of two students at UW-Eau Claire and six students at Northland College. The UW-Eau Claire team used instrumentation in UW-Eau Claire’s chemistry and materials science departments to provide a full array of polymer characterization and mechanical property results for literally hundreds of samples provided by Northland College. The UW-Eau Claire undergraduates also learned synthetic and characterization techniques that were applied to all aspects of transition metal compound preparation and characterization. In addition, several undergraduate members of the research team gained valuable experience by serving as the primary presenters of their results at national research conferences. The collaborative nature of this NSF project drew upon the complementary expertise of the principle investigators and exposed the undergraduates to a wider range of chemistries and research approaches than if the project had been a single investigator award.

At UW-Eau Claire, one undergraduate has completed his baccalaureate degree and is pursuing a master’s degree in materials science at the University of Oregon. The second undergraduate will finish her baccalaureate in May 2020 and plans to pursue a medical career focused on radiology or oncology. Both students used their research experience to augment their graduate school and medical school applications.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2019
Modified by: Michael J Carney
